I haven’t written anything in a while, and didn’t really know if I had any ideas until I sat down and started writing. </p> <p>I explained my creative process to the others in my writing group as feeling like I’m lightning rod — I conduct the words onto the page, from somewhere I don’t know where, rather than feeling like I am creating them. I wrote a poem about the nightmares I had as a child of being carried away by a black bird (the subject of a painting I produced several years ago), a poem about last month’s meteor over Russia, and a poem about desire that without saying so was about self harm, among other things.</p> <p>The others in my writing group came along to the open mike, and a couple also performed — it was good, since I so rarely can have anyone come along to support me on the night. Unexpectedly, a girl I was at school with — but haven’t seen since I was 18 — came into London just for the occasion. We’re Facebook friends, and I’d invited her, but I invite a lot of people and nearly everyone just ignores it — so I didn’t expect to see her. It was nice to see her and interesting to spend time with her. And before it looks like I’m suggesting romantic interest: she’s gay.</p> <p>I liked what I wrote, and I liked how I performed — then we stayed out drinking far too late and I missed the last train home, but it was worth it.</p> <p>Last night was a wholly different open mike night, and this time Camille was performing. Camille is in a show choir, and so her and some of her fellow choir friends went along to practice some songs they are working on. It was a very different sort of night to what I am used to in Shoreditch, this had a range of ages and people, and being a night based more on music had people performing Noel Coward songs and piano pieces as well as reading.</p> <p>I signed up to read myself, but wasn’t sure what to perform myself. When it came to music, it seemed that most people performed covers — so I wondered if it was appropriate to read poems that weren’t my own. I was reassured by a writer friend it would be OK, and she suggested a combination — with reading one of my own, too.</p> <p>In the end, I read Pablo Neruda’s “Tonight I Can Write” (and if I say so myself, I think I read it well — because I know the poem well and have read it aloud many times, though never to a group of people) and carefully selected to read my new poem “The Great Black Bird”, since it didn’t reveal or hint at anything Camille wasn’t aware of.</p> <p>I don’t know if I would attend again, the first half of the night was entirely dedicated to the host singing — and I didn’t much like the songs or his style — but enjoyed the open mike portion. I do wish I could get more people to come and see me perform, but part of my style is so many “things I’ll never say” and can’t be shared with Camille or anyone close to her.</p> stillwater tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/42266 2013-03-16T08:36:18-04:00 2013-03-16T08:36:18-04:00 I just want to be alive <p>It turns out, my work’s attitude towards my relationship with Cerys was only going to be the tip of the iceberg. When I returned from Berlin and my boss had seemed mean and grumpy and given me a hard time about things, including Cerys, that was just the start.</p> <p>I’d told my boss and selected colleagues about my anxiety and depression in the hope they’d get it and get me better, offer me help where I needed it, be more understanding. On Monday I went into my normal Skype meeting with my boss and instead of the usual catch up, I got stuck with a Personal Improvement Plan and told that x, y, and z were wrong with my work, and I had to meet certain goals, or face losing my job.</p> <p>Thanks, guys! That is <i>exactly</i> how you should treat an employee who tells you they have problems with anxiety and depression: give them something to <i>really</i> worry about! I knew the two events were unrelated — a document like this had to be at least a week in the making, before I told them I had problems — but it should have been handled more compassionately.</p> <p>That was nearly two weeks ago now, and I am firmly back on my medication with a promise to myself to not stop taking it like that again. I might be sad and a little anxious most of the time, but I can put a mask on it now, I can cope, I can enjoy myself. Without it, my moods overwhelm me. Though as an interesting side note, I’m aware that my medication (Citalopram, if you are interested) is used to treat anxiety. It’s interesting because anxiety is also a side effect of the medication, and clearly why my anxiety seems worse now I’m tackling my depression.</p> <p>Other side effects include diarrhoea (which once led me to having to practically run out of a Group Cycle class), sexual dysfunction (I was already dysfunctional, so this isn’t great: look up ‘retarded ejaculation’ if you’re interested), distraction, yawning, flatulence and possibly mania. If you’d seen how far down I went when I stopped taking the medication, you’ll understand why these side effects are worth taking the medication for.</p> <p>Things at work have slightly improved. Cerys and I behave professionally in the office, but if we get a chance to be alone together we will still embrace and I’ll still kiss her. Part of me likes that it’s now almost clandestine , Cerys gets playfully annoyed at me when I make it sound sordid. I’m working on my improvement plan and making reasonable progress towards my goals. I produced on target the business plan I was tasked with, and my boss had no criticisms of it. I have to work on my communication and presentation skills, still.</p> <p>I met with HR and took them through my Plan line by line, outlining what I felt was unfair, untrue, inaccurate or ambiguous in it. How my boss will react when HR take this back to her, I don’t know, but Camille encouraged me not to take it lying down and not be seen as a soft target.</p> <p>Recently, though, my thoughts have been returning to the idea that I don’t want to spend my life in marketing. A friend shared with a story from Men’s Fitness magazine, about 10 adventures you can have that beat the traditional vacation — like whale watching for conservation, measuring volcanic activity, tracking animals and Mayan artefacts, that sort of stuff. The trouble is I don’t want a vacation: I want these things to be my life. Right now, I am working myself to the bone just to make money for someone else and for no good reason.</p> <p>I want to be alive.</p> stillwater tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/42223 2013-03-10T20:44:12-04:00 2013-03-10T20:44:12-04:00 Le maillot jaune <p><i>This post is locked. I don’t need this any more!” but because I still felt miserable and had constant thoughts of hurting myself. I saw no point in taking the medication if I still felt like shit, so I started skipping two out of three meals a day, and stopped taking my medication, and decided I didn’t want to feel better and would just rather self destruct.</p> <p>I spent the last week in Berlin, and maybe part of the city — along with the grey skies and cold air — affected my thoughts and my mood. It didn’t help I was stressed trying to manage a large conference for work, and my colleagues were being more complaining than complimentary.</p> <p>When I returned on Thursday, I went straight from the airport to the office. I was due to have a call with my boss in New York at the end of the day, and it made more sense to have it the office to get to my writing group in time.</p> <p>The call wasn’t what I was expected, where we normally catch up and chat about what I’m working on, what I need help with and what’s on my mind, this meeting seemed more to be a bollocking. My colleagues had reported I seemed out of my depth at the conference, and had complained about various things — even though the conference had more than 250 (mostly happy) people, and great speakers.</p> <p>I was also unexpectedly taken to task about my relationship with Cerys. It felt like almost a formal warning — our relationship was not appropriate and unprofessional for the workplace, we are — and I quote — “too touchy-feely”. I am 99% sure it was our colleague the marketing director who must have complained to my boss, since when I walked into the office, Cerys practically ran across the room to meet me, and embraced me in a big hug. I hugged her back hard, kissed her on the top of the head and told her it was good to see her.</p> <p>Yes, we hug and touch and kiss in the office — but it’s not like we are a couple, so we don’t behave like one, if I kiss her it’s not on the lips or in a romantic way, we certainly don’t spend our time making out or worse. It made me very angry, and Cerys understands how I feel. I was especially angry that nobody would have said something quietly to me without going to my manager — who is the community director — behind my back and making it seem like an issue. But I have obliged by moving the storage box from under my desk to form a physical barrier between Cerys and me, and am trying to move things along my desk to force me to sit further away. </p> <p>It seems ridiculous to me that anyone should complain that I am too close or too friendly with a colleague — as I say, we are not sleeping together, we are not in a relationship and don’t behave like we are. Yes, we are close and very affectionate, but that’s also because we understand each other and as two people who suffer from depression, it is nice to have someone around who will hug you when you need it.</p> <p>I made a decision, and contacted HR. Not about Cerys, of course — if that is considered an issue, there isn’t much I can say about it, except be quietly angry. But I told the global HR manager about my problems with depression, anxiety, my medication not helping like it’s supposed to, and how I can’t see a therapist because I can’t afford it. I asked him if I should tell my manager — and the colleagues I report to in whatever way. He replied, sympathetically and understandingly, and gently suggested he thought I should tell them. They can’t understand or help you if they don’t know.</p> <p>I told Cerys the next morning, and she agreed. She thought it was brave, but also thought it would be a good idea. So I told them, in an email. My manager (the community director), the marketing director, and a colleague with whom I will apparently be meeting and sort of reporting to each week.</p> <p>It terrified me to do it. I’ve resisted telling anyone in case they think “What use is a community manager who suffers from anxiety?” and fire me. But I know I am good at my job, and I want to be better at my job, and by being open about these parts of myself perhaps people will understand a bit better and support me.</p> <p>I still don’t know really who to trust. I know I can trust the guy in HR, he told us when we joined we could talk to him about anything, any time, and he would listen and advise without it necessarily going down in our HR record. I know I can trust Cerys with these things about myself. But much more than that, I don’t know who can be trusted — I don’t know who will report things I tell them in confidence, I don’t know who might have something against me. I’ve had colleagues in the past that I was sure were working against me.</p> <p>I found a blank “depression screening form” I found on my desk while trying to tidy it yesterday. I decided to fill it out, and was disturbed my own answers. There were far too many ticks in the fourth column. Admitting to colleagues I had a health problem suggested to me I want to be better and I don’t want to self destruct, so I have decided to start eating and taking my medication again.</p> <p>Also, because I have issues with trust, I might decide to password protect this journal. The password would be freely available to everyone and anyone on cdx, but I worry about others from the outside finding it. For now, I will keep it open — and monitor if I think unwanted visitors are reading.</p> stillwater tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/42161 2013-02-27T04:15:58-05:00 2013-02-27T04:15:58-05:00 Étape 5: La lanterne rouge <p><i>This post is locked. Which isn’t really a surprise, as I sit next to her all day at work every day normally. Except in Miami I must have run up a large telephone bill sending her text messages all the time. Surprisingly for her, she actually replied (I think) to nearly all of them. It’s something that pisses me off with her sometimes at home — the way she often just doesn’t respond to messages, and I feel like I have ceased to exist for her: out of sight, out of mind.</p> <p>Anyway, this week has been spent in her company probably more than usual.</p> <p>I arrived into Miami about two hours later than planned, and was endearingly pleased to see me. I checked in at the hotel, went up to my room and was unpacking when Cerys arrived at my door (I had already texted her my room number). As soon as I opened the door she launched herself at me in a jump-tackle-hug. I gave her my spare room key right away, because that’s just the relationship we have: although I still locked the door at night.</p> <p>Once I was showered and changed, she took me to the carnival party that was that evening’s entertainment at my company meeting, and I spent the evening wandering around, talking warmly to colleagues I’d already met (some many times over the years, before I joined) and colleagues I’d talked to only online. Some clearly knew me better than I knew them as they would strike up a conversation and it would be several minutes before the context or their accent enlightened me.</p> <p>I’ll write more about Miami another day, maybe. Today is for thoughts on Cerys.</p> <p>I’ve said before how I have romantic feelings for her, although these wax and wane depending on the day or my mood. This week there were other guys looking at her like lost puppies, and at least one guy in particular that Cerys confessed to me she was in love with.</p> <p>How Cerys falls in love, or how she describes it, isn’t nearly as confusing as it sounds when she is so besotted with her boyfriend. I told Camille about it, briefly, and we both laughed how Cerys had just a few minutes earlier posted on Facebook how much she was looking to go home and see her boyfriend.</p> <p>Cerys explained it to me perhaps the next day, that she just can’t help but fall in love with people — but it doesn’t mean she wants anything to happen. With Cerys herself firmly in the front of my mind, I told her sincerely that I knew exactly what she meant, of being in love with someone and wanting so badly for them to return your feelings, but also desperately wanting them not to so, because it would be bad and confusing. You long for someone and pine for them and live for their attention and feel cold and abandoned when you don’t get it and learn they love someone else, but at the same time this is exactly the way it has to be.</p> <p>It was a little weird to see her sad to be leaving, and sad to be leaving the company of this guy she had fallen with, even though she was going home to the love of her life. And I thought about my relationship with her, how it will never be the same as that, and about Josephine, and about Camille, and about how the one you love and the one who loves you are never, ever the same person.</p> <p>But I have to keep learning this same lesson, over and over again.</p> stillwater tag:www.codexed.com,2005:Post/42059 2013-02-08T00:42:03-05:00 2013-02-08T00:42:03-05:00 Deafening Silence Silence is different for me.<br/> <br/> Because I forgot what it sounds like.<br/> <br/> The ringing in my left ear has grown in intensity over the last few years.
